event.description: The presentation will deal about how a local community is organising itself to promote Fedora locally. As soon as a new team has given itself the appropriate tools to promote Fedora on the web, it was ready to spread the right words about the principles that govern the Fedora Community.

event.title: Java Status on Fedora
event.abstract: Java Status on Fedora

event.title: Logical Volume Management
event.abstract: Upcoming enhancements to LVM2 and device-mapper.
event.description: LVM2 is the disk volume manager used by both Fedora and CentOS. This presentation will discuss ideas for enhancements to both kernel and userspace packages, including a summary of work already in progress as well as some 'blue sky' thinking. Come along and share your ideas!

event.title: Fedora's plans for 2007 + Q&A
event.abstract: Fedora's plans for 2007, the roadmap, the goals, and Q&A about any topic related to Fedora.

event.title: SystemTap on Fedora
event.abstract: SystemTap is a tool for gathering and investigating system-wide information about a running Linux system.
event.description: SystemTap eliminates the tedious instrument, compile, reinstall, reboot sequence involved in data collection.

event.title: GDB Tracepoints
event.abstract: GDB and tracepoint debugging
event.description:
Tracepoint debugging allows a developer to observe a program as it runs with minimal impact on its real-time behavior.

Jim's work, building on the Linux kprobes facility and GDB's existing tracepoint support, allows GDB to debug the Linux kernel it is running under, using source-level expressions and source code locations.

event.title: The future of the Bugday project
event.abstract:
The talk will be about how the Bugday project is evolving at the moment with all the new team members and new ideas.

It will be a completely non-technical talk.

event.title: What makes Gentoo a community based distribution?
event.abstract: What makes Gentoo a community based distribution ?

event.title: Gentoo's inner working: The Council
event.abstract: more details soon

event.title: Java on Gentoo
event.abstract: In this talk, Gentoo/Recruiting co-lead and Gentoo java developer Petteri Räty, provides an overview of Java support for Gentoo Linux.
event.description:
The Gentoo/Java project provides support for Java on everyone's favorite Linux distro, Gentoo Linux.

The project provides a wide variety of Java runtimes and development kits, applications, libraries, and utilities. This talk will provide an overview of what you can expect from Gentoo as a Java user or developer.

The Java team has for some years successfully used overlays as a way to involve users so this talk also provides ideas on how to get involved in Gentoo development using overlays.

event.title: Portage - A look under the surface
event.abstract: This talk will take a closer look at some of the new Portage features added in the Portage-2.1 series and how they can be used.
event.description: It will also discuss some commonly requested features and try to explain why they haven't been implemented yet.

event.title: Programing with Paludis
event.abstract: Programing with Paludis
event.description: Introductory talk in Paludis' paradigm and how to use its C++ and Ruby API.

event.title: Release Engineering: Tinderbox testing
event.abstract: Gentoo Release Engineering, Genkernel, and the Catalyst Release-building tool.
event.description: The talk will cover the Gentoo Release Engineering release cycle, Gentoo hosted projects catalyst and genkernel, and also the release Engineering automated build scripts/system that is used to locate problems before the release cycle begins.

event.title: Bling it up - make it sexy!
event.abstract: The talk "Bling it up - make it sexy!" will present certain ways how to achieve embellishment for your own application-development using cairo, librsvg and other usual suspects.
event.description:
The presented techniques will be demonstrated with the help of a bling'ed up example program written in C. There will be gradients, rounded corners, blurs, fades, animation and so on... and sourcecode.

The intended audience is expected to already know a bit about cairo and gtk+. It will not be a talk for beginners.

event.title: Overview of the Gnome Developer Platform
event.abstract: The talk will introduce the Gnome Development Platform to new developers.
event.description:
The talk will cover the components and technologies that are available, how they are related and how to get started using them.

The session will leave time for questions. The goal is to use the feedback to improve the offered platform documentation.

event.title: Easy databases with Glom
event.abstract: Easy databases with Glom

event.title: Welcome
event.abstract: Welcome to the GNOME/KDE integration developer room.
event.description: Sunday morning is shared with KDE for common topics and KDE/GNOME integration.

event.title: Why do we do it ?
event.abstract: Navigating the minefield: a personal guide to contributing to free software

event.title: GNUstep Database Library 2
event.abstract: [[http://www.gnustep.org/resources/documentation/Developer/GDL2/GDL2.html] GNUstep Database Library 2]

event.title: GNUstep for Embedded Devices
event.abstract: GNUstep for Embedded Devices e.g. Zaurus or Mobile Phones
event.description:
The recent announcement of the Apple iPhone - which is reported to use Cocoa for the GUI - has again shown that Objective-C and the OpenSTEP system can really be used in embedded devices.

Topics to cover in this presentation:

  • why does one want to run GNUstep on embededed devices?
  • what is different on embedded devices?
  • what is needed to develop applications for embedded devices?
  • why is it currently run as a separate project (mySTEP)?
  • examples: Sharp Zaurus, Acer n30, Nokia N770, OpenMoko, ...

event.title: Étoilé: a Desktop Environment
event.abstract: Étoilé: a Desktop Environment

event.title: FortyTwo Semistructured DB
event.abstract: FortyTwo – Towards a Semistructured Database System
event.description:
Agenda:

  • About the Project
    • Motivation
    • Theoretical Background
  • Architecture
    • Data- and Servicemodel
    • Architectural Overview of FortyTwo
  • Positioning
    • Comparison with other semistructured database systems, with Coredata etc.
  • Showtime
    • Demonstration
    • Current State
  • Summary and future Directions

event.title: Secure Communications with Jabber
event.abstract: In this talk, Peter Saint-Andre will discuss the existing security features of Jabber technologies and how they are being extended to ensure complete privacy of communication over the Internet.
event.description:
When you chat with a friend in your living room or a colleague in your office, you expect the conversation to be private. Unfortunately, your online conversations may not be private -- it all depends on what technology you use.

There are many reasons why Jabber is more secure than existing IM and presence technologies, so Peter will explain those and how they help prevent spam on the Jabber network.

He will also talk about the Intermediate Certification Authority that Jabber recently launched to issue free digital certificates for Jabber servers. Finally he will talk about the end-to-end encryption technology they are developing for complete privacy of instant messaging.

event.title: Jaiku: Jabber the mobile
event.abstract: How to map a desktop IM protocol for mobile use: Jaiku combines rich presence and group messaging on the web and on the mobile, powered by Jabber.
event.description:
After an introduction into Jaiku, this presentation shows how Jaiku uses XMPP protocols and highlights the associated challenges, touching on network coverage, battery usage, sporadic attention, low input-rates.

The presentation closes with a small demo.

event.title: Give me a Jingle
event.abstract: The Jingle XEPs add support to XMPP for session-based features such as voice, video and file transfer.
event.description: This talk will discuss the justification for these extensions, what they are trying to achieve, and how they work, taking a look at the current state of the standards and their implementations.

event.title: OneTeam
event.abstract:
A Mozilla/XUL Jabber application.

OneTeam is a Mozilla based client, focusing on the enterprise market and introducing innovative productivity oriented features. It can be run from the web or as a standalone desktop client.
event.description: This talk will describe the design approach behind the new OneTeam client, the target features and the project roadmap. The talk will close with a demonstration of OneTeam's most current version. We will then provide accounts to visitors, to access the Web version after the talk.

event.title: Follow-up Q&A and Lightning Talks
event.abstract: As a follow-up to his talk in the Internet Services track on 'Secure Communications with Jabber', this Q&A session with Peter Saint-Andre provides more time for answering questions.
event.description: Also, last-minute lightning talks (5 min. each) will be scheduled in at the end of this slot.

event.title: Jabber Sprint using Twisted
event.abstract: This short software development spree (sprint) is intended for developers to get acquainted with developing special purpose Jabber clients and server-side components.
event.description:
We will use Twisted to explain several protocol concepts in detail and show how to deal with asynchronous protocol handling.

Twisted is an event-driven networking framework written in Python. It excels in writing applications that use one or more networking protocols in an asynchronous fashion, without resorting to multi-threading. Twisted includes implementations of a large number of protocols, among which XMPP.

event.title: Distro DevJam
event.abstract: The goal of this session is to improve the distro packaging guidelines (filesystem layout, packaging inter-dependencies, browser integration, jpackage.org integration, developer guidelines, etc.) used across GNU/Linux distributions for Java libraries and programs.
event.description: Success for the DevJam would be demonstrated by community agreement towards cross-distro Java policy augmented by distro specific developer guidelines for implementing the policy.

event.title: OpenJDK
event.abstract: Sun will discuss the roadmap for the OpenJDK project including goals and code release plans.
event.description:
Sun will ask the community to participate in a discussion of governance models and contribution policies as to facilitate platform innovation while respecting the Java Community Process (JCP).

Current operations plans for version control, bug tracking, patch submission and testing will also be covered.

Engineers from the compiler team, the HotSpot team, the Java2D team and the Quality team will also give technical lightning talks.

This will be an interactive session with plenty of opportunities to ask Sun questions about OpenJDK.

links.link: [PDF] Peter von der Ahé: Java compiler

event.title: JBoss BPM
event.abstract: Open source moving up the stack to JBoss BPM: a deep look at BPM in the scope of JBoss jBPM, focusing on the benefits for the developers.
event.description:
Open source moves up the stack. From OS, over application server and now to BPM. BPM is typically associated with high level business analysis and not having to write code.

This session will give a different perspective. In fact, there are many process languages: some targeted for business analysts, some targeted at specific aspects of software development. An example of the latter could be the overview of asynchronous architectures. The focus will be on the benefits for the developers. Also we include a good description of how BPM is more about improving communication between business analysts and developers, rather then trying to avoid coding.

event.title: KDE e.V.
event.abstract: KDE e.V. - The organization behind the project
event.description: A big Free Software project such as the KDE e.V. needs some administrative care. This talks outlines the why and the how of KDE e.V. the foundation that is the legal representative of the KDE project. The mission of KDE e.V. is to support the development in the project.

event.title: Free Educational Software: working together
event.abstract: With the emergence of educational Linux distributions, Free Educational Software begins to reach schools. This BoF aims to make all people involved in Edutainment (packagers, developers, ...) meet together and present their work in order to start collaborating better.

event.title: KDE 4
event.abstract: KDE4 - where are we and where are we going.
event.description:
Jos will outline what the current status of the KDE 4.0 development cycle is, and what the KDE project wants to archieve in the KDE 4 series.

Some screenshots showing the current new stuff.

event.title: Krita: Present and Future
event.abstract: Krita is the painting and image editing suite for KOffice. The talk will focus on its recent developments and the future KDE4 version.
event.description:
Krita has been innovating itself for a while now. Already available features interesting for image editing include the possibility of CMYK colors and 16 bit per channel, while other features like a basic watercolor simulation could interest artists.

The next version of Krita will be based on the new KDE4 and KOffice2 technologies. The long-awaited change towards KDE4 for development provided a great incentive to reshape the whole of KOffice, and Krita will be using these new architectures to provide an even better integration with the rest of the KOffice suite. This intermingling goes both ways: not only will Krita be able to have better support for embedding other applications, the whole of KOffice now shares libraries that were already present in Krita 1.6.

This talk will consist of two parts. One part will be looking at the recent changes and features in the last KDE3 based 1.6 branch. The other part will try to give an overview of the more interesting features that are scheduled for the next KDE4 based release, offering a view at what could be expected.

event.title: GPG/PGP Keysigning
event.abstract: GPG/PGP Key Signing session.
event.description: See http://fosdem.org/2007/keysigning#gpg for details.

event.title: LPI exam session 3
event.abstract: LPI Exam session #3
event.description: See http://fosdem.org/2007/lpi

event.title: LPI exam session 4
event.abstract: LPI Exam Session #4
event.description: See http://fosdem.org/2007/lpi

event.title: LPI exam session 5
event.abstract: LPI Exam Session #5
event.description: See http://fosdem.org/2007/lpi

event.title: Amarok
event.abstract: A lightning talk about Amarok, a jukebox audio player
event.description:
In this talk the speaker will show advanced and hard to find features of Amarok.

About Amarok:

Amarok is an audio player with jukebox capabilities and many useful, partly well hidden features.

event.title: Babel Free Auditing System
event.abstract: A lightning talk about Babel, a security auditing system.
event.description:
The lightningtalk will be a graphical demonstration about how Babel works.

About Babel Enterprise:

Babel is an enterprise-grade auditing system to manage a consistency on security policy between different systems in a non-homogeneus architecture. Babel allows to manage very different operating systems, like AIX, Solaris, Windows 2000, Windows XP, Linux, *BSD or HPUX.

Babel allows administrator team to monitor the hardening level of their systems and keep constantly monitored, using periodic policy polling, and of course, a WEB Based, graphical reporting, and of course, a centralized management for all systems.

Babel uses a pragmatic point of view and try to evaluate security aspects on your systems that could be improved by the administrators. Babel is not intrusive, it only collect information and manage all this information.

Currently we are working with agents for Solaris, AIX, WindowsXP/2000/2003 and GNU/Linux versions (Debian, Ubuntu and SUSE).

event.title: Balloon Open Hardware License
event.abstract: A lightning talk about the Balloon Open Hardware License.
event.description:
The talk will be primarily about the Balloon Open Hardware Licence on which we are currently solicting feedback. It will explain why the licence is different from software Licences, distinguishing between designers, manufacturers, and users, who needs different rights and protections. We are actively seeking feedback on this Licence, in order to make it widely suitable. A short history of the Balloon Project and current status will be included.

About the Balloon Project:

Balloonboard is primarily about the design and use of the Balloon series of open hardware boards. First Balloon hardware was in 2002, and Balloon2 was used in products of a couple of companies, for Disabled speech sythesisers and seismometers. Balloon3 is now out, with built-in FPGA, being used in University teaching (robotics) via the Cambridge/MIT MDP.

We have created a new Open Hardware licence suitable for all such Open Hardware, and are keen to see Balloon spread to other educational institutions and products, and the licence be refined and used elsewher.

event.title: CCAPI2
event.abstract: A lightning talk about CCAPI2, an algorithm trading platform.
event.description:
The presentation will create in fifteen minutes a full trade system, that will be backtested against a prerecorded market situation. The outcome of this trading day is then presented and quickly discussed.

About CCAPI2:

The CCAPI2 is an algorithm trading plattform. With CCAPI2, users can create automated trade systems for trading stocks, futures, commodities and other financial instruments. The project contains forums, documentation, a mailing list and proper release cycles. At this time, seven more or less active developers take care of the 150 downloads per month.

event.title: LogiLogi Manta
event.abstract: A lightning talk about LogiLogi Manta, an incremental and entity-oriented discussion environment.
event.description:
The speaker will talk about FOSS (especially web 2.0) for the humanities, about the ideas behind LogiLogi Manta, like entity-oriented philosophy and combining full openness with quality-control, and last but not least about LogiLogi Manta itself.

About LogiLogi Manta:

LogiLogi Manta targets on making incremental and entity- oriented philosophical discussions possible. Core values are openness, relativism and quality of content. Manta is bringing together the idea of writeups of everything2.com and the transparency of Wiki's and the posibillity for rating content from multiple viewpoints, hierarchical tagging, meaningfull urls, link-types, and more.

Manta was started with a modest grant from the Philosophy department of the (Dutch) Rijksuniversiteit Groningen.

event.title: Mapyrus
event.abstract: A lightning talk about Mapyrus, software for creating PostScript plots.
event.description:
This talk is a quick introduction to Mapyrus, describing how it provides a scripting/BASIC type language for drawing shapes, labels and images to various graphics output formats. The method of combining sequences of steps to create different types of output will be shown.

Several nice features of Mapyrus will be demonstrated, such as transparent colours and use of blending modes, user-defined TrueType and PostScript fonts, using clipping polygons to avoid drawing inside/outside an area, protecting areas of page to avoid over-lapping labels or symbols and a sinkhole algorithm for finding position for labelling polygons.

Finally, some real world mapping and charting applications of Mapyrus will be shown, using data read from Geographic Information Systems (GIS) mapping datasets and a relational database.

About Mapyrus:

Mapyrus is Java software built on the Java2D library for creating plots of points, lines, polygons and labels to PostScript (high resolution, up to A0 paper size), Portable Document Format (PDF), Scalable Vector Graphics (SVG) format and web image output formats.

Mapyrus is released under the LGPL license.

event.title: MetaLinks
event.abstract: A lightning talk about MetaLinks: XML mirror lists.
event.description:
The lightning talk will cover a basic metalink, what problem metalinks hope to solve and what support for them is already out there, showing the difference between Metalinks and some other solutions currently used.

About MetaLinks:

The Metalinks tools project is there to create tools to handle and generate Metalinks. Metalinks are XML mirror lists with verification information (and more). Currently the project has created a command line tool to generate these files and the Metalink standard is already supported by mutliple download managers (see http://metalinker.org/ for a full list). Metalinker.org is where the XML format specs and general information about Metalinks can be found (including news).

event.title: Mozart-Oz
event.abstract: A lightning talk about Mozart-Oz: a multi-paradigm programming language.
event.description: This talk will introduce Mozart-Oz, a multi-paradigm programming language supporting functional, concurrent, object-oriented, logic and constraint programming paradigms, offering transparent support for distributed programming. Recently, the project has moved from a Consortium of Universities to a more open governance model in order to welcome new developers. This programming language is being used for development in some European projects and for teaching at universities in Belgium, Sweden, Poland, Colombia and USA, using the book "Concepts, Techniques, and Models of Computer Programming". Unfortunately, it is not well known out of the academia and we would like to present it to the FOSDEM community.

event.title: OpenEmbedded
event.abstract: A lightning talk about OpenEmbedded, and other build-systems.
event.description:
OpenEmbedded can be classified as build-system. It heavily relies on build-systems of Free Software projects. Exactly this will be the content of the lightning talk. We will take a look at badly written buildsystems including fontconfig and glibc, understand why these things are bad and how these issues can be resolved. At the end we will look into some requirements you should take into account when picking a buildsystem for your project.

About OpenEmbedded:

Deterministic and flexible system to build Embedded Linux Distributions, Toolchains and Packages

event.title: OpenOffice.org port for Mac OS X
event.abstract: A lightning talk about the Mac OS X port of OpenOffice.org
event.description:
• what is Mac port inside the project
  • people: who / where
  • communication between developers, tools
  • how works the project : schedule, QA, issues, development management
  • development problems : marry fully OpenSource project with non-open source platform is not so easy, find resources
About OpenOffice.org: OpenOffice.org project ( http://www.openoffice.org ) is a fully Open Source project, with a good portability on several platform / OS

event.title: OSSIE
event.abstract: A lightning talk about OSSIE, a Software Defined Radios(SDR) implementation.
event.description:
The talk will introduce software defined radio and talk about several open source SDR projects. The talk will focus on explaining what SDR is, why the open source developer would be interested in it, and ways to get started.

About OSSIE:

OSSIE is an implementation of the Software Communication Architecture(SCA). The SCA provides a structure for implementing Software Defined Radios (SDR) using a component based architecture. OSSIE currently runs on regular PC's and a TI OMAP Starter Kit (OSK). OSSIE runs primarily on Linux based machines (although other Unix's should work OK).

event.title: phpAspect
event.abstract: A lightning talk about phpAspect, aspect-oriented programming in PHP.
event.description:
The talk will be a quick overview of phpAspect and demonstrates how this tool can be used to modularize web-specifics crosscutting concerns like XSS faillures with a very simple use case.

About phpAspect:

In software engineering, the programming paradigm of aspect-oriented programming (AOP), attempts to aid programmers in the separation of technical concerns (persistence, logging, etc) from the business logic. This paradigm introduce a software entity, called aspect which, thanks to a mechanism of weaving, can enrich portions of business logic with technical processes. In phpAspect this mechanism of weaving uses XSLT to perform source code transformation.

event.title: PSPP
event.abstract: A lightning talk about PSPP: a Free replacement for SPSS.
event.description:
The proprietary program called SPSS is widely used by the medics, psychologists and social scientists. For many years there has been no Free program to replace it. PSPP is an emulation of this proprietary program, designed to facilitate the transition to a Free desktop for traditonal SPSS users. I'll be presenting what PSPP currently does now, what it may do in the future and how it could interact with other Free Software programs.

About PSPP:

PSPP is a program for statistical analysis of sampled data. It interprets commands in the SPSS language and produces tabular output in ASCII, PostScript, or HTML format.

PSPP development is ongoing. It already supports a large subset of SPSS's transformation language. Its statistical procedure support is currently limited, but growing.

event.title: ReaR
event.abstract: A lightning talk on Relax and Recover, a disaster recovery framework.
event.description:
Short presentation on Rear (history, architecture, design, purpose). A live demo (movie) of a real disaster recovery process will be shown during the talk.

About ReaR:

Relax and Recover (abbreviated rear) is a highly modular disaster recovery framework for GNU/Linux based systems, but can be easily extended to other UNIX alike systems. The disaster recovery information (and maybe the backups) can be stored via the network, local on hard disks or USB devices, DVD/CD-R, tape, etc. The result is also a bootable image that is capable of booting via PXE, DVD/CD and tape (OBDR).

event.title: SIP Communicator
event.abstract: A lightning talk about SIP Communicator, an audi/video softphone and IM client.
event.description:
The talk would first go over major features of SIP Communicator and describe what sets it apart from a user point of view.

It would then describe aspects of the project that might be of interest to FOSS developers. One of the key characteristics of SIP Communicator is its flexibility and easy to use API. The client is built around an OSGi (www.osgi.org) core. All its functionalities are implemented as independent modules that also export services for use by plugin developers. This part of the talk would try to show how easy it is to use these services and create plugins for SIP Communicator or directly get involved and contribute to its development.

About SIP Communicator:

SIP Communicator is an open source (LGPL) audio/video Internet phone and instant messenger that supports some of the most popular instant messaging and telephony protocols such as SIP, Jabber, AIM/ICQ, MSN and soon others like Yahoo and IRC.

event.title: Zzuf
event.abstract: A lightning talk about Zzuf, an input fuzzing bug hunter.
event.description:
This talk will present zzuf's internals and give a few examples of real life bugs in various widespread end-user applications that zzuf is able to find automatically.

About Zzuf:

zzuf is a transparent application input fuzzer. Its purpose is to find bugs in applications by corrupting their user-contributed input. It works by intercepting file and network operations and changing random bits in the program's input. zzuf's behaviour is deterministic, making it easier to reproduce bugs.

event.title: Metasploit Framework
event.abstract: The Metasploit Framework is an open-source platform for developing and using exploit code.
event.description: This talk will cover the new features and development resources available in version 3.0 and some of the challenges faced by the project during the development process.

event.title: Turbocharging Linux with Mono
event.abstract: In this talk Miguel will discuss how they are using Mono at Novell to increase the joy of programming and increase their productivity.
event.description:
He will also discuss their efforts to assist Windows developers move their software to Linux, what they are providing to those developers today and what is in store for the future.

Miguel shall also showcase some major endorsements of Mono.

event.title: Mozilla
event.abstract: (details will follow)

event.title: AllPeers: Experiences with Mozilla and Future Plans
event.abstract: This talk will have two parts. In the first part, we discuss the benefits and challenges of building a complex application as a Firefox extension. In the second part, we discuss our future plans, with a specific focus on upcoming features of Mozilla that we are excited about and things that we would like to see added to Mozilla.
event.description:
With AllPeers we have faced the unusual challenge of building a relatively large and complex application as a Firefox extension. This means that, unlike projects like Flock and Songbird, we have not been able to change the underlying Mozilla code base when it hasn't fully met our requirements.

We discuss some of the specific issues we have faced (thread safety, RDF, encoding issues, integration with third-party libraries, etc.) and the solutions that we found. We also mention some of the main strengths of Firefox as a platform that have helped our project to be a success.

In the second part of the talk, we go over some of our future plans. This includes adding true support for BitTorrent to Firefox in the short term, a strategy for efficient generation of HTML from a SQL datasource ("Mozilla Server Pages") and our longer term plan to split AllPeers into two parts: a XULRunner-based engine and a much smaller Firefox extension that will serve as the user interface.

The latter will solve some of the issues we have experienced with hosting the entire application in Firefox and will open the way to layering alternative UIs (such as Internet Explorer) on top of our Mozilla-based engine.

event.title: Mozilla Localization status report
event.abstract:
Mozilla Localization teams, a status report and whishlist.

Return of experience, wishes of the localisation teams (and specially the french one).

Tools proposition.
event.description:
Outline :

  1. Introduction
  2. How do we work in the frenchmozilla team
  3. Wishes and improvement (from the french team and others)
  4. Proposition of a tool
  5. Conclusion
  6. Discussion

event.title: L20n - A localization architecture proposal
event.abstract: Localizing software is still a challenge and a compromise between programming effort and localization quality. The talk will outline some unsolved issues so far and propose a new architecture to tackle those.
event.description:
Localization of software brings up the same problems in every project, and not all of them have solutions so far. After analyzing the common requirements in the wild and within the Mozilla applications in particular, we found no existing architecture being able to bring the localization quality to software that users deserve.

L20n is the code name for a proposed architecture that changes the way programs handle locale-dependent strings such that the quality of the localization is only limited by the amount of work a localizers spends, and not limited by architectural problems. We will show common localization pitfalls along with the proposed solutions.

L20n is designed with Mozilla applications in mind, but should be interesting for other applications and frameworks, both for locally installed applications and web applications. We hope for participation from non-Mozilla hackers and localizers in particular at FOSDEM, and reserve a good deal of the allocated time for discussions.

event.title: QA mozilla/xulrunner based applications
event.abstract: Challenges encountered doing QA on a xulrunner based application. QAing Joost (tm)

event.title: Releasing Mozilla Localizations
event.abstract: Mozilla will use the gathering of many of its European Localizers to discuss various aspects around releasing existing and new localizations of the Mozilla products.
event.description:
We will have a series of discussions on various topics. The actual list of topics as well as the time spent on each will depend on what we actually need, but expect topics like Documentation, Build, Tools, Release process etc to be handled.

These won't really be talks, and Axel will only moderate the discussions.

event.title: Extension Development with Thunderbird
event.abstract: An overview of how OpenPGP is integrated into Thunderbird, including the problems that the OpenPGP standards cause for mail clients.
event.description: Enigmail is tightly integrated into Thunderbird. This is often not as straightforward as it may seem, since OpenPGP standards are incompatible to several email standards and implementation approaches used by Thunderbird. This talk gives an overview on these problems and how they are addressed.

event.title: Open Groupware: OGo/JOPE/SOPE
event.abstract: Open Groupware: OGo / JOPE / SOPE

event.title: openSUSE Community
event.abstract: A talk from an openSUSE Community member on Community history, ongoings, problems, challenges, and plans for the future.
event.description: openSUSE, since SUSE Linux 10.0, is open up to the public with beta-testing; development and the release process is no longer all in-house. This talk will cover some thoughts on the response of such a change, other problems and challenges that the community is facing, as well as exciting projects made by the community.

event.title: Usability research of KDE at openSUSE
event.abstract: The KDE team at SUSE has been applying usability research principles to the user interfaces they design. This talk presents their research methodology and the resulting applications.
event.description:
The Interfaces and Applications team at the SUSE research and development department in Nuremberg, Germany is composed of usability experts and KDE developers. The team evaluated the start menus of common desktops including KDE 3.5, the GNOME main menu developed for SUSE Linux Enterprise 10 Desktop and Windows Vista Beta 2.

Central to this research is a usability study where about 30 users of different types are divided up into four groups to perform a test cycle with three phases:

  • Questionnaire: user's habits during use of their commonly used start menu
  • Observation: execution of 13 different tasks stored on videotape for later evaluation
  • Questionnaire: user's evaluation of the given start menu (joy of use, suitability to the task, controllability, etc.)
This aKademy talk will summarize the findings of these ongoing tests including showing video excerpts. The whole team then discussed the central functionality that an improved start menu for KDE 4 should have, and with the test results in mind, brain-stormed and produced mockups. For further discussion and testing a prototype, code-named 'Kickoff', was produced and iteratively refined. To validate this design, a fourth group of users repeated the usability tests with the prototype to get data for a comparison of old and new designs. The talk will present major points of the discussion and results and of course will not miss to showcase the current 'Kickoff' version.

event.title: Documentation: Lessons for Lizards
event.abstract:
A New Open Source Documentation Project: Lessons for Lizards

Lessons for Lizards (LfL) is a community cookbook-style book project for the openSUSE distribution licensed under the GFDL.
event.description:
This talk will introduce the Lessons for Lizards project, show how to participate in this project, and present the tools available.

Lessons for Lizards will ship with upcoming openSUSE releases on an equal footing with internally produced documentation. It covers more specific or exotic topics than the internally produced manuals (such as experimental software or complex setups).

One aim of the LfL project is to enable the openSUSE community to actively participate in the openSUSE documentation. The other aim is to provide a cookbook for beginners and experts with step-by-step recipes and hands-on guides for topics not covered in the present documentation.

The book should be easy to write. To make this possible, SUSE provides a technical environment (SVN server, wiki), software (tools and scripts) and support (documentation, mailinglist).

event.title: Mono Workshop
event.abstract: The Mono workshop gives more details on how to work with mono.
event.description: The Mono workshop gives more details on how to work with mono. The workshop after Miguels Mono talk, so you have the chance to get more information here.

event.title: OpenOffice - OpenXML
event.abstract: A talk about the OpenXML integration in OpenOffice

event.title: OpenSync
event.abstract:
OpenSync - Synchronization Framework for mobile devices.

A short introduction of OpenSync, a Synchronization Framework. The Framework is intended to synchronize all kind of mobile devices, applications and services. The talk includes some details about the features of the upcoming OpenSync 0.30 version.
event.description: OpenSync is a Synchronization Framework. The framework is a desktop independent synchronization solution for all kind of mobile device and application. The plugin based architecture allows to enhance the support of new devices/protocols with providing a simple plugin. There are so far OpenSync frontends for the command line, KDE and GNOME. At the moment framework supports: SyncML, IrMC and many other protocols and the KDE PIM and Evolution environment.

event.title: Suspend to disk and to RAM
event.abstract: Suspend to disk and to RAM, reports about the current state and workshop
event.description:
Suspend to disk and to RAM, reports about the current state.

After the Talk there will be a workshop, if you have problems with suspend this is the chance to work on it with the speakers and get your Laptop working with suspend.

event.title: ThinkFinger
event.abstract:
ThinkFinger - Don't bother if you lose your password, but please keep your finger safe.

Introduction on ThinkFinger, a driver for the UPEK/STM fingerprint reader. The device is being found either as a standalone USB device, built into USB keyboards or built into laptops (Dell, IBM/Lenovo, Toshiba).
event.description:
ThinkFinger is a driver for the UPEK/SGS Thomson Microelectronics fingerprint reader (USB ID 0483:2016).

The device is being found either as a standalone USB device, built into USB keyboards or built into laptops. The following laptop vendors are using the device:

  • Dell
  • IBM/Lenovo
  • Toshiba
Toshiba is shipping their laptops either with the UPEK/SGS Thomson Microelectronics fingerprint reader or with a fingerprint reader built by AuthenTec. The AuthenTec fingerprint reader is *not* supported by ThinkFinger. SONY laptops with the UPEK/SGS Thomson Microelectronics fingerprint reader are not supported. ThinkFinger is devided into two parts: libthinkfinger and pam_thinkfinger. libthinkfinger is a library to be used in order to communicate with the fingerprint reader. The talk will give insights about the low-level engineering (usbmon), the library as well as the PAM module.

event.title: Common package and patch management for SUSE Linux
event.abstract: Zypp - SUSE package management
event.description:
Zypp is the integration of SUSE's yast2 Package manager and Ximian's libredcarpet. At Novell we used two solutions so far - Red Carpet and YaST package manager - and decided to merge both in a best of breed approach. Zypp features brings SUSE package management technology to a world of new possibilities like runtime dependencies on hardware, patterns, full-featured patches and Zenworks integration for a easy enterprise upgrade path.

In this talk this technologies will be presented among the current integration of them into the products, the problems faced during the transition and the current roadmap for the future releases.

event.title: Plone 3.0
event.abstract: Developer Preview of Plone 3.0
event.description:
Plone has become a popular choice for managing content with security, workflow, translations, and other services.

In this talk we preview the important changes planned in Plone 3.0 for developing add-ons and customized sites with Plone.

event.title: Profiling Desktop Applications
event.abstract: In this talk Federico will examine the basics of how to do a performance investigation, of which profiling is just one part.
event.description:
Performance has to be focused on tangible benefits: will users stop noticing an annoying delay ? Will making an operation faster make the program more usable ? Will I get more transactions per second, and do I really need them ?

Doing an analysis of performance makes you feel good for various reasons: you end up using the scientific method, you get to really understand the code you are fixing, and you learn many obscure techniques along the way.

After this talk you will know how to do a performance investigation, and you will know about the basic tools you can use to profile your programs.

event.title: Elisa
event.abstract: Elisa is a project to create an open source cross platform media center solution.
event.description:
While our primary development and deployment platform is GNU/Linux and Unix operating systems we also currently support Microsoft Windows and also hope to support MacOSX in the future.

Elisa runs on top of the GStreamer multimedia framework. In addition to personal video recorder functionality (PVR) and Music Jukebox support, Elisa will also interoperate with devices following the DLNA standard like Intel's ViiV systems.

The talk is about Elisa's history, its current features, how it interoperates with devices and other applications. Philippe will also explain the plans for Elisa as well as a little demo.

event.title: Extending Python
event.abstract: Learn why and how to extend Python using ctypes and Pyrex.
event.description: Python comes with batteries included, but sometimes you need more. And even more often you need faster batteries that reuse C/C++ libraries. Pyrex, the pseudo language, and ctypes helps you in order to bind C libraries to Python modules. Includes real pieces of code.

event.title: ModularBot
event.abstract: ModularBot, a modular IRC bot written using Python.
event.description: Pierre will show how to write something modular, since it's easy and often interesting to do. He will also try to show some funny things about the Python introspection features...

event.title: Quality in Python
event.abstract: «Bind two birds together: they have twice as many wings. However they are unable to fly.» Best practices in Python explained.
event.description: Quality often come too late in a project life cycle. Python's rigour helps making a project more maintainable but it isn't enough. Better practices can help you being more effective. Code styles, testing, documentation, project packaging best practices explained.

event.title: SQLAlchemy and Elixir
event.abstract: A short presentation of SQLAlchemy (the Python SQL toolkit and Object Relational Mapper) and Elixir, which is a brand-new declarative layer on top of SQLAlchemy, with a syntax similar to that of Ruby on Rails's ActiveRecord.
event.description: SQLAlchemy acts as the glue between your python projects and your SQL database in a very elegant way. It is a very powerful tool but setting up everything can be a bit tedious, so we wrote Elixir, as a thin wrapper around SQLAlchemy to provide the ability to define model objects in a simpler (and quicker) way when you do not need the full expressiveness of SQLAlchemy's manual mapper definitions.

event.title: XML processing with ElementTree and lxml
event.abstract: Python 2.5 now includes the ElementTree XML processing module to process XML documents and streams in an efficient, straightforward, pythonic way. This talk introduces the API on common use cases.
event.description:
We also introduce a second implementation of the same API: lxml. This library based on libxml2/libxslt add further implement standard XPATH queries, XSTL processing and validation against schemas (XML Schema and RelaxNG).

We will finally demonstrate sample usage of those libraries to process ODF and SVG documents.

event.title: The Zope3 component architecture
event.abstract: The aim of this talk is to show the use of the zope.interface module to formalize duck typing in python projects.
event.description: By contractualizing APIs, a python project can gain much modularity and then make it natural to plug objects together in a reusable thanks to the delegation pattern implemented by the zope.component sister module.

event.title: Research and Libre Software (II)
event.abstract: Presentation of reviewed short papers.
event.description:
• Snapshot on the EDOS distribution system: Radu Pop
  • New generation of Linux Meta-installers: Paulo Trezentos
  • Determining developer habits and intuition through the use of interactive chat sessions: Martin F Krafft
  • Identifying challenges for a productive and sustainable Open Source ecosystem: Jens Hardings

event.title: Panels and open discussion
event.abstract: Panel: Issues of Company Involvement in Open Source Software Projects
event.description:
• Motivation and presentation: Matthias Stuermer (chair)
  • Firms' involvement in the projects of the OS community (short presentation): Cristina Rossi
  • Open discussion
  • Research and libre software:
- what can research about libre software contribute to libre software development; - what do developers feel about research - some academics and developers (3 min. position talk each, then open discussion)

event.title: Samba
event.abstract: Current State of Samba
event.description: Samba has been around a long time, and just keeps trucking along, right ? Not quite... Attend this talk to hear about what's new in Samba, what the Samba3/Samba4 code is all about, why we aren't an Active Directory Domain Controller yet (and why it's hard) and why the CIFS protocol is likely to loom large in *your* future, even if you use nothing but Linux...

event.title: Security Testing
event.abstract: Security testing not by the book
event.description:
A cheat sheet to efficient and accurate security testing and analysis, this overview is about what many penetration testers and ethical hackers just don't get. The real world doesn't conform 100% to rules but it is rules that get put into tools and courses which guide and often think for today's security professionals. In this talk, we will examine various real-world networks, services, and applications and explain where the tester went wrong in the test and analysis.

Security testing is the means to measure and verify operational security and controls are working. The Open Source Security Testing Methodology Manual (OSSTMM) is an open, peer-reviewed specification for an accurate and thorough security test. The OSSTMM has been written for real-world security testing and metrics and a review of the last 4 years of OSSTMM research is used to create this interactive talk.

event.title: Nouveau: What's new ?
event.abstract: Introduction of Nouveau, a new 3D-capable opensource display driver for nVidia GPUs.
event.description:
In this talk, I will first introduce the nouveau project quickly.

This project aims at improving the quality of open source drivers for nvidia cards. Targetted features include 3D, dual head support, better 2D/Xv support, deobfuscating the code, and much more.

I will introduce the project, talk about past and current developments, and try to peek at my crystal ball for future works.

event.title: Second Life
event.abstract: Second Life opens the source code: what happens when a company frees their software BEFORE they jump the shark
event.description:
Aaron Brashears from Linden Lab discusses what happens when a company with a proprietary code base decides to open it up, and talk about some of the contributions that have already come in and some of the things that have the community buzzing (such as the community effort to design a plugin architecture).

There will be a discussion of the architectural elements of the Second Life viewer, some of the ideas Linden Lab has for the future of the project, and what new technology is coming down the pipe for release.

event.title: X security framework
event.abstract: A framework to add security policies which meet the needs of specific environments and use cases in place.
event.description:
The original design of the X Window system treated all application as 'friends'. Applications (i.e.) X clients had access to data, state information and resources of each other. Many use cases don't allow such a policy. In environments where the protection of confidentiality matters this behavior is undesirable.

The first attempt to overcome this was the X-Security extension. It presented a fixed and rather simplistic security policy. It had proven itself to be unflexible and not useful.

Here we present a framework to add security policies which meet the needs of the specific environment and use case in place.

event.title: X.org Video Driver API Update
event.abstract: Unification of X.org video driver APIs
event.description: The X.org video driver API has not supported the full range of hardware capabilities for several years. The resulting driver-specific mechanisms have made general configuration systems hard and provided diverse capabilities not based on hardware abilities, but rather on the vageries of the development process. Unifying these interfaces and exposing common configuration mechanisms serves to both homogenize the X server functionality across all hardware platforms as well as provide an interface for new RandR functionality.

event.title: Video on Dope
event.abstract: Video on Dope - Different Techniques to Accelerate XVideo Display with OpenGL
event.description:
XVideo with color keying has been notoriously problematic in the past (multiple heads, size restrictions, etc.), and it doesn't work well with composited desktops.

For OpenGL-based compositing window managers like compiz and for OpenGL-based Xservers like Xgl the most straight-forward solution is to use OpenGL for doing the color conversion and scaling on-the-fly. On the other hand, OpenGL is so flexible that there is more than a single way to implement this - and all techniques have their advantages and drawbacks.
